author: kamil_chodola
content: <@301186049323958275> Can you birefly elaborate on your concerns about state growth vs gas limit increase? Like realistically when and how it will affect solo stakers?

author: sky.cactus
content: Stakers aren't the problem.  I care very little about them as they are paid service providers and can buy specialized hardware and dedicate time to operations.

author: sky.cactus
content: The problem is that in order for a user to interact with Ethereum, they need to be able to execute arbitrary transactions and read arbitrary state.  This requires their front end communicating with a node that has the full head state.  This let's them check balances, query AMM pools, participate in games, etc.

author: sky.cactus
content: If they want to do that trustless, they need a node of their own that has the head state, or they need to talk to a node with head state who can provide them execution proofs that they can validate.  If they want to interact with Ethereum privately, they can't even do the latter.

author: sky.cactus
content: Such a user can prune all of history up to the most recent finality, and many clients already support various types of pruning.  The state, however, is something they cannot avoid having.

author: sky.cactus
content: Right now state fits in under 100GB if you don't store any MPT data, something like 250GB with MPT.  Pruning this is hard if it is in MPT form, and currently there is no trustless way to maintain head without the MPT.

author: sky.cactus
content: Right now you need at least 500GB, realistically closer to 1TB to run a node that maintains head state.  With R&D (that is not being done!) we could get that down to under 100GB.

author: sky.cactus
content: This is all context to say that state growth of 100s of GB per year is massive when put into that perspective.  Increasing state growth will have a severe impact on what kind of hardware end users can use to privately and trustless interact with Ethereum.

content: Here are Steam stats for free space that gamers have.  This is a demographic I would expect to have bigger drives than most people.

author: sky.cactus
content: The average **user** does not have 4TB of free disk space.  They have under 51GB of free space, probably less than 256GB on average.  If we want real users to be able to trustlessly interact with Ethereum then we need to be extremely careful with how big we allow state to grow.

author: sky.cactus
content: This doesn't even get into discussion about network bandwidth on home internet connections.
